Name: Two Statues of King Senusert the Third
Description: These two statues were headless when first found, but the text on the rear supports of both statues identified them as belonging to King Senusert the Third.Three years later the heads were found and attached to the statues. The statues are nearly identical. They represent the king standing with his left leg forward. He is wearing the royal Shendyt kilt with the central flap, a necklace with an amulet, and a false beard. One statue shows the king wearing the White Crown and the other depicts him wearing the Red Crown. This symbolizes the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt during his reign.
